section.para: The element agent specifies a person or organization that played a direct or indirect role in preparing, creating, or editing the data.

At least one <agent> must have an <IRI> that is a tag URN whose namespace matches that of the IRI name. By default, the first such <agent> is taken to be the person or organization ultimately responsible for the current file.

May also be applied to a computer or algorithm that performed a task. This feature is useful for crediting software, e.g., an OCR program used to convert an image, or an algorithm that estimates word-to-word alignments.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@roles?, @xml:id, (<comment>* & (<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)))))
Used by:

listitem.para: To attach responsibility for the TAN file to a person or organization, at least one agent must have an IRI element that contains a tag URI whose namespace matches that of the URI name

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <declarations> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> <IRI>http://viaf.org/viaf/299582703</IRI> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Joel Kalvesmaki</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ........... </role> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <declarations> <work include="master"/> <div-type include="master"/> <recommended-tokenization which="general-words-only-1"/> <recommended-div-type-refs>implicit</recommended-div-type-refs> ........... </declarations> <agent include="master"/> <role include="master"/> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <declarations> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> <IRI>http://viaf.org/viaf/299582703</IRI> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Joel Kalvesmaki</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ........... </role> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <declarations> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="park" roles="editor"> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Jenny Park</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ........... </role> ........... </head>

section.para: The element agentrole specifies a time period when one or more <agent>s held one or more <role>s.
Definition: (@include | (@when-from, @when-to, (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @who, @roles))
Used by:
The element body contains the data

Definition: @in-progress?, (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (<comment>* & [[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} (<equate-works>*, <equate-div-types>*, <split-leaf-div-at>?, <realign>*, <align>*) OR {TAN-A-tok.rng:} (@bitext-relation, @reuse-type, <align>+) OR {TAN-LM.rng:} (@lexicon, @morphology, <ana>+) OR {TAN-R-mor.rng:} (<assert>* & <report>* & <category>* & <option>*) OR {TAN-R-tok.rng:} (<replace>*, <tokenize>, <example>+) OR {TAN-T.rng:} (@xml:lang, <div>+)]])
Used by:

example.programlisting:
...........
...........
...........
...........
...........

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs-dupl" TAN-version="1"> <head> ........... </head> <body xml:lang="grc" ed-who="kalvesmaki" ed-when="2015-08-02T15:31:07.816-04:00"> <div include="master"/> </body> </TAN-T>

...........
...........
...........
...........
...........

...........
...........
...........

section.para: The element change declares a change made to the current file. Must credit an <agent>, specified by @who, and a time the change was made, specified by @when.
Collectively, <change> elements form the changelog, the revision history of the document.
The editor has discretion as to how long or detailed a <change> should be, or how many should be retained in a changelog. Ideally, <change>s documenting every published version should be retained.
<change> elements may appear in any order, but it is good practice to put the most recent at the top.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @when, @who, text
Used by:

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <role xml:id="editor"> ........... </role> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs-dupl" TAN-version="1"> <head> ........... <role include="master"/> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head> </TAN-T>

<head> ........... <role xml:id="editor"> ........... </role> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

section.para: The element checksum specifies some checksum that can be used to confirm the identity of a digital file being referred to. This element contains other elements that define the type and value of the checksum. Must begin with an IRI + name pattern that defines the type of checksum being used (e.g., SHA-1).
This element is useful when it is imperative to ensure that one is using the identical version of a source file.
The checksum will not be generated, checked, or validated by TAN schemas. Validation must be provided by an external tool.
Definition: (<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)), <value>
Used by:

example.programlisting: <source> ........... <name>TEI transcription of boundary marker, set up by C. Julius Zoilos</name> <checksum> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sha-1</IRI> <name>SHA-1</name> <value>8ac1146c86e06071f352bf3cb89614c0a0f0c7ee</value> </checksum> <location when-accessed="2015-05-07">http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/iaph2007/xml/iAph010001.xml</location> </source>

section.para: The element comment discusses issues relevant to nearby data. Must credit an <agent>, specified by @who, and a time the comment was made, specified by @when.
Definition: @when, @who, text
Used by:

example.programlisting: <source> ........... <name>The traditional games of England, Scotland, and Ireland : with tunes, singing-rhymes, and methods of playing according to the variants extant and recorded in different parts of the Kingdom</name> <comment when="2015-03-10" who="park">This work is to be found at vol. 2, pp. 108-111.</comment> </source>
<head> ........... <change when="2014-08-13" who="schmidt">Anfang</change> <comment when="2014-08-13" who="schmidt">unten auf der Z. 438, recht</comment> </head>
<head> ........... <change when="2014-10-24" who="park">Started file</change> <comment when="2014-10-24" who="park">See p. 39 of source.</comment> </head>

<snippets-to-turn-into-real-TAN-examples> ........... <change when="2015-02-04" who="cheh" ed-when="2015-02-28" ed-who="smith">Cheh corrected all xml:lang values</change> <comment> In this example, <change> ascribes an alteration to Cheh, but the edit stamp credits Smith with last changing the <change>.</comment> </snippets-to-turn-into-real-TAN-examples>

section.para: The element declarations contains assumptions or decisions made that materially affect the interpretation of the data in <body>

Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (<comment>* & ( & [[ {TAN-class-1.rng:} ((<work> & <version>? & <div-type>+ & <recommended-tokenization>+ & <recommended-div-type-refs>? & <filter>?) & ) OR {TAN-class-2.rng:} (([[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} <tokenization>* OR {TAN-class-2.rng:} <tokenization>+]] & [[ {TAN-class-2.rng:} <suppress-div-types>* OR {TAN-LM.rng:} <suppress-div-types>?]] & <implicit-div-type-refs>* & (<rename-div-types>*, <rename-div-ns>*)) & [[ {TAN-A-tok.rng:} (<bitext-relation>+, <reuse-type>++) OR {TAN-LM.rng:} (<lexicon>+ & <morphology>+)]]) OR {TAN-class-3.rng:} ( & [[ {TAN-R-mor.rng:} (<for-lang>+ & <feature>+) OR {TAN-R-tok.rng:} <for-lang>*]])]]))
Used by:

listitem.para: In a TAN-A-tok file, if there is a source/@include, then an entire set of sources are being imported, and, consequently, every declaration in the inclusion must also be included

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Add declaration Choosing this option will insert the first missing child of the declarations element. If multiple declarations are missing, repeat as needed.
Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with inclusion Choosing this option will replace a child element of declarations with one that specifies @include to point to the value of source/@include

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <see-also> ........... </see-also> <declarations> <work> ........... </work> <div-type xml:id="p"> ........... </div-type> <div-type xml:id="c"> ........... </div-type> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <see-also> ........... </see-also> <declarations> <work include="master"/> <div-type include="master"/> <recommended-tokenization which="general-words-only-1"/> ........... </declarations> <agent include="master"/> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <see-also> ........... </see-also> <declarations> <work> ........... </work> <div-type xml:id="ch"> ........... </div-type> <div-type xml:id="par"> ........... </div-type> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <source> ........... </source> <declarations> <work> ........... </work> <div-type xml:id="sect"> ........... </div-type> <div-type xml:id="var"> ........... </div-type> ........... </declarations> <agent xml:id="park" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> ........... </head>

section.para: The element desc provides a human-readable description of a concept, person, or thing referred to by the parent element (or the current document, if the parent element is <head>). <desc> is, in effect, a <comment> about that concept, person, or thing.

Because TAN files may need to be shared across language communities, this data can be stated any number of times in any language (probably in conjunction with @xml:lang), in any Unicode-compliant script. If you provide a comment in multiple languages, it best to make sure that each version says roughly the same thing.
Definition: ((@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @xml:lang?, string (pattern (.|\n)+))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources>

<rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <declarations> <div-type xml:id="ic"> ........... <name>independent clause</name> <desc>used to identify two or more sentence parts that have a subject and predicate and function as a sentence.</desc> </div-type> </declarations> </head> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element flags specifies flags to be applied in an XPath expression using regular expressions.
s = dot-all mode; m = multi-line mode; i = case-insensitive mode; x = remove whitespace characters from regular expression; q = no metacharacters
For more see http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-30/#flags
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, string (pattern [smixq]+)
Used by:
The element for-lang specifies a language discussed by the TAN file. This element does NOT name the language of the text enclosed by the parent element, which is the province of @xml:lang.
Values should adhere to BCP (Best Common Practices) 47, http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt. For more details see main.xml#language.
Examples: 'eng' (English), 'grc' (classical Greek), 'lat' (Latin)
Definition: language
Used by:

example.programlisting: <declarations ed-when="2015-03-03" ed-who="kalvesmaki"> <for-lang>eng</for-lang> <feature xml:id="quote-cl"> ........... </feature> ........... </declarations>

section.para: The element head contains the metadata (data about the data contained by <body>)

Indicates at a bare minimum the name of the file, the sources, the most significant parts of the editorial history; the linguistic or scholarly conventions that have been adopted in creating the data; the license, i.e., who holds what rights to the data, and what kind of reuse is allowed; the persons, organizations, or entities that helped create the data, and the roles played by each.

Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (<comment>* & (((<name>+, <desc>*), <master-location>*), <rights-excluding-sources>, <inclusion>*, [[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} <source>+ OR {TAN-A-tok.rng:} (<source>, <source>) OR {TAN-class-3.rng:} <source>* OR {TAN-core.rng:} <source> OR {TAN-LM.rng:} <source>]], <see-also>*, <declarations>, <agent>+, <role>+, <agentrole>*, <change>+))
Used by:

listitem.para: Any TAN file marked as being no longer in progress must have at least one master-location.
No duplication of @xml:ids is permitted

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Add master-location element after <name> with fixed URL Choosing this option will insert a master-location immediately after name, with the absolute value of the current file's URL.

Schematron Quick Fix: Add master-location element after <name> with relative URL Choosing this option will insert a master-location immediately after name, with the simple filename current file (i.e., no path).

example.programlisting: <TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head> <body xml:lang="grc"> ........... </body> </TAN-T>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs-dupl" TAN-version="1"> <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <inclusion xml:id="master"> ........... </inclusion> ........... </head> <body xml:lang="grc" ed-who="kalvesmaki" ed-when="2015-08-02T15:31:07.816-04:00"> ........... </body> </TAN-T>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head> <body xml:lang="grc" ed-who="kalvesmaki" ed-when="2015-08-02T15:31:07.816-04:00"> ........... </body> </TAN-T>

<TEI TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:gomme.1898.ring-o-roses"> <teiHeader type="text"> ........... </teiHeader> <head> <name>Dictionary entry by Alice Bertha Gomme on Ring a Ring o' Roses</name> <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> ........... </head> <text> ........... </text> </TEI>

section.para: The element inclusion specifies a TAN file that is available for inclusion. An inclusion occurs whenever an element X points to this inclusion by means of @include. TAN-compliant validators and processors will fin every X that is found in the included file (checked recursively, against any inclusions adopted by the inclusion) and insert them at that place in the main document.
Only the elements of that name X will be included, not the entire inclusion file. It is up to you to specify exactly which elements should be included.
You may include as many <inclusion>s as you wish, and do not have to use them all.
If you are using an <inclusion> primarily for metadata (<head>) it is recommended to put the value of @xml:id in uppercase. <body> inclusions should be set in lowercase.
For more on this, see main.xml#inclusions
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @xml:id, (<comment>* & (<IRI>, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+))
Used by:

listitem.para: No inclusion may introduce a duplicate @xml:id
Inclusion has the same tag id as this document.
Every inclusion must have at least one location that leads to an available document.

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <inclusion xml:id="master"> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <location when-accessed="2015-09-17-04:00">file:/Users/joelk/Dropbox/TAN/SERVER/release/1/dev/examples/ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-sem.xml</location> </inclusion> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head>

section.para: The element IRI contains an International Resource Identifier that serves as a name for the a concept, person, or thing referred to by the parent element. IRIs are explained at main.xml#IRIs_and_linked_data.

Any kind of IRIs are allowed: URLs, tag URNs, UUIDs, etc. For names of well-known resources, a URL identifier might be preferred (http://...), to facilitate linked data. If an entity/resource lacks a suitable URL-type name, you may use or coin any other valid IRI, such as a UUID, a tag URN, or an OID. Some concepts may be difficult to find IRIs for. See iris.xml for guidance.

Sibling <IRI>s are to be treated as names for the same thing, not as names of different things. Nevertheless, they are not synonymous, only poecilonymic. In the terms of Web Ontology Language (http://www.w3.org/TR/owl-ref/), sibling <IRI>s cannot be assumed to share the relationship owl:sameAs, because they will draw from independent vocabularies that may define similar concepts differently. An element defined with multiple <IRI>s is to be understood as being within the intersection of those definitions.
The element is named IRI instead of URI to encourage internationalization. Alphabets other than the Latin are welcome.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, anyURI (pattern [a-zA-Z][\-.+a-zA-Z0-9]+:\S+)
Used by:

listitem.para: No duplication allowed: an IRI should appear only once in a file.
If referring to a TAN file, the value must be a tag URN that matches exactly the TAN id

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with TAN id of 1st document available Choosing this option will replace the content of an IRI element with the value of the TAN id

example.programlisting: <TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> <IRI>http://lccn.loc.gov/50036648</IRI> <name>L. Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> ........... </see-also> <declarations> <work> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Categories_(Aristotle)</IRI> <name>Aristotle, Categories</name> </work> </declarations> </head> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element location declares where an electronic file was found, when.
The URL may be absolute or relative to the current document.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @when-accessed, anyURI
Used by:

listitem.para: If a file that is referenced is either unavailable or not valid XML, a warning will be returned
If a referenced file is marked as being in progress, a warning will be returned
If a TAN file has been updated since it was last accessed, a warning will be returned
If a sibling <name> or <IRI> is missing, a warning will be returned

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with local uri Choosing this option replace the content with the current filename (without path)
Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date Choosing this option will replace the content of @when-accessed with the current date

Schematron Quick Fix: Replace IRI and name with target values Choosing this option for a TAN file will replace the content of the IRI and name elements with the values found in the first document available.

example.programlisting: <see-also> ........... <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> <location when-accessed="2015-09-11-04:00">ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-sem.xml</location> </see-also>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs-dupl" TAN-version="1"> <head> <inclusion xml:id="master"> ........... <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <location when-accessed="2015-09-17-04:00">file:/Users/joelk/Dropbox/TAN/SERVER/release/1/dev/examples/ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-sem.xml</location> </inclusion> <see-also> ........... <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, object-based references</name> <location when-accessed="2015-09-11-04:00">ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-obj.xml</location> </see-also> </head> </TAN-T>

<see-also> ........... <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, object-based references</name> <location ed-when="" when-accessed="2015-09-11-04:00">ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-obj.xml</location> </see-also>

section.para: The element master-location points to a location where a master copy of the file is to be found. When you use <master-location> you commit yourself to updating the TAN file in those locations. Similarly, if you have completed work on a TAN file and signal that through @in-progress, you must commit yourself to a <master-location>.
The URL may be absolute or relative to the current document.
<master-location> does not disallow the file from being published or distributed elsewhere. It merely points to the main locations where an authoritative version of the file is to be found.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, anyURI
Used by:

listitem.para: Any TAN file marked as being no longer in progress must have at least one master-location.

example.programlisting: <head> <name>Dictionary entry by Alice Bertha Gomme on Ring a Ring o' Roses</name> <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> ........... </head>

<head> <name>TAN Transkription, Ringelreihen mit Riederfallen</name> <master-location>http://beispiel.com/TAN-T/ringel.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="schmidt"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> ........... </head>

<head> <name>TAN transcription of Ring a Ring o' Roses</name> <master-location>ring-o-roses.eng.1881.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> ........... </head>

<head> <name>TAN transcription of 1790 version of Ring around the Rosie reported by Newell in 1883</name> <master-location>ring-o-roses.eng.1957.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> ........... </head>

section.para: The element name provides a human-readable name of a concept, person, or thing referred to by the parent element (or the current document, if the parent element is <head>)

Because TAN files may need to be shared across language communities, this data can be stated any number of times in any language (probably in conjunction with @xml:lang), in any Unicode-compliant script.
Definition: ((@ed-who, @ed-when)?, @xml:lang?, string (pattern (.|\n)+))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> <IRI>http://lccn.loc.gov/50036648</IRI> <name>L. Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> ........... <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> <location when-accessed="2015-09-11-04:00">ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello-sem.xml</location> </see-also> </head> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element pattern specifies a regular expression pattern to be searched for or matched
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, text
Used by:

listitem.para: Every escape sequence must be recognized by XML schema. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#regexs for details.

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tarn-r-tok:general-1"> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Pad every cluster of non-word characters with space.</comment> <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>\s+</pattern> </tokenize> </body> </TAN-R-tok>
<replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Remove end nonword characters</comment> <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>

section.para: The element relationship specifies the role that the item named by the parent <see-also> played. This may be either a reserved keyword or an IRI + name pattern that identifies a specific kind of relationship.

Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | ((<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)) | string (pattern (new|old) version|(parent|child|ancestor|descendant|cousin) edition|alternatively (divided|normalized) edition|dependent|auxiliary)))
Used by:

listitem.para: Unless you define a relationship through an IRI + name pattern, the value must be:

example.programlisting: <see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> ........... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> ........... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> ........... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship>cousin edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt</IRI> ........... </see-also>

section.para: The element replace constructs the equivalent of an the XPath replace() function plus parameters. Used in class 1 and class 3 (TAN-R-tok) files.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@xpath?, (<comment>* & (<pattern>, <replacement>, <flags>?))))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tarn-r-tok:general-1"> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Pad every cluster of non-word characters with space.</comment> <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ........... </tokenize> ........... </body> </TAN-R-tok>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Remove end nonword characters</comment> <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ........... </tokenize> ........... </body>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-18" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ........... </tokenize> ........... </body>

section.para: Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, text
Used by:

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tarn-r-tok:general-1"> <head> ........... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <declarations/> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="creator"> ........... </agent> ........... </head> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> ........... <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> ........... <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> </body> </TAN-R-tok>
<replace> ........... <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>
<replace> ........... <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>

section.para: The element rights-excluding-sources states the license under which the data is distributed and the rights associated with it, EXCLUSIVE of any rights attached to the source.

If parts of your TAN data fall under two or more licenses, you should (1) split the file (one for each license), (2) find a license that sythesizes the desired licenses, or (3) release the entire file under the most restrictive of the possible licenses.

Diligently check to ensure that the license you have claimed respects the rights of your sources' rightsholders. It is recommended that you license your data under a license that is similar to or slightly more liberal than the one under which your sources have been released.
For more discussion, see main.xml#license
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@rights-holder, (<comment>* & (<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)))))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head>

<head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <inclusion xml:id="master"> ........... </inclusion> ........... </head>

<head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>This data file is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. The license is granted independent of rights and licenses associated with the source. </name> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ........... </source> ........... </head>

section.para: The element rights-source-only states license and rights that are attached to the source of the data.
For more discussion, see main.xml#license
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (<comment>* & (@rights-holder*, (<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)))))
Used by:
The element role specifies a role (responsibility, task, or activity) that one or more <agent>s did in creating or editing the data.
A role may be any activity, e.g., editor, funder, supervisor, data-processor, peer reviewer, patron, defined through the enclosed IRI + name pattern.
For suggestions on IRI vocabularies for this element, see iris.xml.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@xml:id, (<comment>* & (<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)))))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

<head> ........... <declarations> <work include="master"/> <div-type include="master"/> <recommended-tokenization which="general-words-only-1"/> <recommended-div-type-refs>implicit</recommended-div-type-refs> ........... </declarations> <agent include="master"/> <role include="master"/> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <agent xml:id="park" roles="editor"> ........... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-03-10" who="park">Created new TAN-TEI file.</change> </head>

section.para: The element see-also identifies auxiliary entities that were materially helpful in creating or editing the data, or are helpful in understanding the data.
This element is especially useful for may be used to credit 3rd parties who provide a set of raw data that you then edit to bring into better conformity with the <source>.

Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (<comment>* & (<relationship>, ((<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)) | |(<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+) | |(<IRI>, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+)))))
Used by:

listitem.para: In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same source.
In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same work.
In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same work-version.
In class 1 files, alternatively divided editions must preserve identical transcriptions.

If relationship keyword is
new version
old version
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition
alternatively divided edition
alternatively normalized edition
dependent then parent element must point to TAN file.

If relationship keyword is
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition then parent element must point to a TAN file of the same time as the current file.
If relationship is dependent, then the current document's id must be found in at least one IRI in the dependent file.

If relationship keyword is
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition then the current file and the see-also file cannot have the same @id value.

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <source> ........... </source> <see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> ........... </see-also> <declarations> ........... </declarations> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <source> ........... </source> <see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, object-based references</name> ........... </see-also> <declarations> ........... </declarations> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <source> ........... </source> <see-also> <relationship>alternatively divided edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, object-based references</name> ........... </see-also> <declarations> ........... </declarations> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <source xml:id="ger"> ........... </source> <see-also> <relationship>cousin edition</relationship> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt</IRI> <name>Edition that renames div types, values</name> ........... </see-also> <declarations> ........... </declarations> ........... </head>

section.para: The element source identifies the source upon which the data in the <body> of the current file depends.
TAN-T and TAN-LM allow only one <source>. TAN-A-tok allows exactly two. All other TAN formats require one or more.

Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | ([[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} @xml:id OR {TAN-A-tok.rng:} @xml:id OR {TAN-class-3.rng:} @xml:id?]], (<comment>* & (((<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*)) | |(<IRI>+, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+) | |(<IRI>, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+)), <rights-source-only>?))))
Used by:

listitem.para: At least one copy of each source must be available to validate file.
After declarations are applied, source must preserve the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule.
Any TAN file with more than one source must provide an @xml:id to label the source.
Upon validation, if a source is found to have a <see-also> that has a <relationship> of 'new-version', a warning will be returned indicating that an updated version is available

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with new version If the source is found to have a see-also that has a relationship of 'new-version', choosing this option will replace the IRI + name pattern with the one in the source file's see-also.
Schematron Quick Fix: Insert @xml:id Choose this option to add an @xml:id to a source element that requires an id value.

example.programlisting: <head> ........... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> <IRI>http://lccn.loc.gov/50036648</IRI> <name>L. Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> ........... </see-also> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <inclusion xml:id="master"> ........... </inclusion> <source> <IRI>http://lccn.loc.gov/50036648</IRI> <name>L. Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> ........... </see-also> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> <IRI>http://lccn.loc.gov/50036648</IRI> <name>L. Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> ........... </see-also> ........... </head>

<head> ........... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ........... </rights-excluding-sources> <source> <IRI>http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/2779087</IRI> <name>The traditional games of England, Scotland, and Ireland : with tunes, singing-rhymes, and methods of playing according to the variants extant and recorded in different parts of the Kingdom</name> <comment when="2015-03-10" who="park">This work is to be found at vol. 2, pp. 108-111.</comment> </source> <declarations> ........... </declarations> ........... </head>

section.para: The element tokenize constructs the equivalent of an XPath replace() function plus parameters. Used in class 1 and class 3 (TAN-R-tok) files.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (<comment>* & (<pattern>, <flags>?)))
Used by:

example.programlisting: <body in-progress="false"> ........... <replace> ........... </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>\s+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ........... </example> </body>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> ........... </replace> <tokenize> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Tokenize on any cluster of nonword characters.</comment> <pattern>\W+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ........... </example> </body>
<body in-progress="false"> <replace> ........... </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>[\s]+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ........... </example> </body>

section.para: The element value states the value of a <checksum>
Definition: string
Used by:

example.programlisting: <checksum> ........... <name>SHA-1</name> <value>8ac1146c86e06071f352bf3cb89614c0a0f0c7ee</value> </checksum>
